body.p:
James H. Lowry states that he was one of the Justices of the Peace who presided at the examining trial of John J. McAfee on the 9th day of August 1861 -- in the town of Nicholasville Ky -- under a Warrant for shooting with intent to Kill = and that in affixing the Bail of said McAfee at the sum of $4000 he was in a great degree influenced by the Consideration & fact that the Wm McDowell the person charged to have been shot by said McAfee was at the time of said trail in a doubtful Condition -- it being then supposed & feared he would die -- but still survives with a prospect of recovery -- & the further facts & consideration of the great excitement & political prejudice as much as personal enmity existing in the Community against the said McAfee = ^in consequence of the occurrance^ & the outside threats and demonstrations indicating mobocracy toward McAfee = he was inclined to the opinion & belief that it was to the interest ^ of & the peace of the Community at large -- to affix said Bail as high as he did = & but for these considerations he should not ^have^ affixed the Bail so high as he did -- and for these reasons he thinks the security of said McAfee are entitled to the Clement Consideration of the Executive of this state --
September 16th 1861 --
